title: 113_s1224
content: The Civil Justice Tax Fairness Act of 2013 is cited as the short title. It excludes certain amounts received on account of unlawful discrimination from gross income. The Civil Justice Tax Fairness Act of 2013 excludes amounts received on account of unlawful discrimination from gross income, including backpay, frontpay, and punitive damages. The term 'unlawful discrimination' is defined as per section 62(e) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Civil Justice Tax Fairness Act of 2013 excludes amounts received on account of unlawful discrimination from gross income, including backpay, frontpay, and punitive damages. This applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. The Civil Justice Tax Fairness Act of 2013 excludes employment discrimination backpay and frontpay from taxable income, limiting the tax liability to the sum of the tax without the backpay or frontpay included in income, plus the product of the number of years in the backpay period and frontpay period multiplied by the tax amount. The Civil Justice Tax Fairness Act of 2013 excludes employment discrimination backpay and frontpay from taxable income. This includes backpay or frontpay receivable on account of unlawful employment discrimination, with definitions provided for terms such as unlawful employment discrimination, backpay, and frontpay. The Civil Justice Tax Fairness Act of 2013 excludes backpay and frontpay from taxable income if attributable to services performed or to be performed before the taxable year for the employer, former employer, or prospective employer, and received on account of a judgment. The Civil Justice Tax Fairness Act of 2013 excludes backpay and frontpay from taxable income if received on account of a judgment for a violation of law. The backpay period refers to the period of services to which backpay is attributable, while the frontpay period refers to the period of foregone employment to which frontpay is attributable. The average annual net backpay and frontpay amount is calculated based on these definitions. The term 'average annual net backpay and frontpay amount' is defined as the excess of employment discrimination backpay and frontpay over allowable deductions, divided by the number of years in the backpay and frontpay period. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 4. Income averaging for backpay and frontpay received on account of certain unlawful employment discrimination will not increase alternative minimum tax liability. Effective Date: Amendments apply to amounts received in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 excludes income averaging for employment discrimination backpay and frontpay from computing the regular tax. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2012.
